important_phrase: Gulf Coast crude oil inventories declined further in December and reached their lowest level in three years
Manufacturing varied by industry, with defense, steel, and energy-related production reporting positive activity, while construction-related goods production remained weak
Input costs continue to increase for goods originating in Europe or Japan because of the lower value of the dollar
Credit card lending was a notable exception to the general tightening in credit standards
However, producers of residential housing-related goods continued to note very weak demand
Residential construction was significantly below year-ago levels across the District, and builders and Realtors reported that weak conditions are expected to persist during the first quarter
Reports concerning tourism continued to be quite positive
Closing out 2007 with mixed results, business  contacts in the First District express considerable uncertainty about 2008
Sales of aircraft equipment and pharmaceuticals continue to grow at a  robust rate, while demand for home construction products continues to decline
In most markets and sectors, rents  and vacancies are flat and sales activity is slow
Inventory levels are mixed, but  several contacts note they are higher than expected because of decreased sales
Hog prices rebounded, but were still below the prices of last year
Residential construction continued to decline, and nonresidential construction showed signs of slowing
The slowdown in construction led to further declines in wallboard prices
However, uncertainty concerning economic conditions in the coming year limited the demand for long-term borrowing
Labor market conditions softened slightly in the District
Nonresidential rents were steady or down slightly
Consumer spending continued to be mixed, with slower retail sales in some areas of the District and slight increases in others
Oil and gas production has been steady to increasing over the past six weeks, although several producers noted a slight decline in drilling activity due to seasonal factors
Economic activity in the Fourth District expanded at a slow pace since mid November
The residential mortgage market remains very sluggish with little expectation for any improvement during the next six months
Stel shipments were mixed
Concerns about labor costs were limited to increases for health care coverage
Vendor prices were steady to increasing during the past six weeks; increases were largely limited to food products
Crop yields were steady
Service sector activity has slowed some but is still quite strong
Labor markets softened
Respondents say consumer demand has softened because of high energy costs and a general concern about economic slowing
Demand for plastics and petrochemicals has slowed
Traffic was slower than usual in December, and contacts say this suggests sales may weaken in January
Retail sales continued to weaken since the last report
The strongest growth in drilling occurred in Oklahoma and Colorado, while winter drilling restrictions may have seasonally slowed expansion activity in Woming
Manufacturing growth improved slightly, and District manufacturers were relatively upbeat
Labor shortages decreased slightly since November, while there was a slight increase in the number of firms expecting to hire in the next three months
Bankers reported somewhat weaker loan demand, slightly tighter credit standards, and a moderate decline in deposits since the last survey
Manufacturing activity grew moderately in December and firms were generally upbeat about future activity, although there were some exceptions
Expectations for sales volume improved slightly from the previous survey, but remained generally negative
Few specific goods stood out as having particularly strong or weak sales, with the exception of relatively soft sales for gasoline and housing-related materials
Farmers were reporting some difficulty storing the huge fall harvest
The Ninth District economy grew modestly since the last report
Overall increases in wages were moderate
A contact at an automation company reported slow activity in December
Commercial construction activity grew at a slower pace
Consumer spending during the holidays was up slightly
Kansas City reported that strong demand and low inventories boosted prices and income for crop producers
Wge increases remained moderate overall
In the San Francisco District, price inflation was said to be limited in general, but significant for food and energy
Several Districts reported declines in loan quality and increased delinquencies
New York reported that manufacturing activity appeared to weaken somewhat in early December, but noted some improvement later in the month
Most contacts anticipate a slower pace of commercial development during 2008
Kansas City reported that spending was solid, but below expectations
Economic growth in the Second District has slowed  since the last report, though the labor market has remained fairly firm
For all loan categories, respondents  indicate further tightening of credit standards
New York Stte manufacturers report that  business activity weakened somewhat as of early December, but note some  improvement in recent weeks
There was some slowing in leasing activity  throughout the metro area, though vacancy rates were little changed, while  asking rents rose modestly
Overall,  it appears that sales were flat to up modestly from 2006 levels
Commercial building leasing and sales have slowed
Most of the firms reporting on employment costs in December indicated that wage increases remained moderate
Looking ahead, bankers generally foresee slow growth in overall lending

?
The outlook in the Third District manufacturing sector is positive, although the level of optimism has declined somewhat recently
Contacts said the decline in leverage in commercial real estate financing has put a brake on building price increases
Most dealers indicated that inventories have been fairly steady at manageable levels
There were pockets of improvement, however
Turning to labor markets, the pace of hiring moderated in recent weeks, though wage growth was steady
Fifth District temporary employment agents continued to report generally strong demand for workers in recent weeks
Interest rates on mortgages edged lower and credit standards tightened a bit further since our last report
Contacts at services firms reported slower revenue growth since our last report, which they attributed to a growing sense of uncertainty among their customers
Outside of residential markets, commercial real estate conditions softened in December and early January
Similarly, a large home improvement retail chain said same store sales were below year-ago levels, due in large part to continued softness in housing
Demand for agricultural products continued to expand
Upward price pressures were limited in general but significant for food and energy, and increases in labor compensation remained moderate on net
District contacts reported that price inflation was modest overall, although upward pressure remained strong for food and energy-intensive items
Lending standards remained relatively restrictive for residential mortgages and construction loans, and scattered reports pointed to further tightening for consumer and business borrowers in general
Food manufacturers saw continued brisk sales gains, while apparel makers reported weak order growth and concerns about cancellations
Mortgage availability and terms remained tight and continued to be a significant constraint on home purchases in many areas
The main exception to weak holiday sales was consumer electronics products, for which sales grew briskly
Total commercial red meat production increased by 8 percent in November over year-earlier levels, but decreased by 4 percent from October
Economic activity in the Eighth District expanded modestly since our previous report
Over the same period, total deposits at these banks decreased , percent
Auto sales were flat over the same period
Contacts in Evansville, Indiana, reported significant commercial activity in the area but noted tighter underwriting on loans and anticipate a slight slowdown after the first quarter
